block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

Bosnian Serb Leader Is Said to Lose Election The Bosnian Serb leader Biljana Plavsic, left, a key player in American strategy in Bosnia, appeared to have been voted out of office, according to international officials monitoring preliminary results of last weekend's elections. Mrs. Plavsic, president of the Serbian republic in Bosnia, was apparently defeated by Nikola Poplasen, the leader of the Serb Radical Party, the officials said. A1
INTERNATIONAL A3-13

Bosnian Serb Leader Is Said to Lose Election The Bosnian Serb leader Biljana Plavsic, left, a key player in American strategy in Bosnia, appeared to have been voted out of office, according to international officials monitoring preliminary results of last weekend's elections. Mrs. Plavsic, president of the Serbian republic in Bosnia, was apparently defeated by Nikola Poplasen, the leader of the Serb Radical Party, the officials said. A1

Basque Rebels Call Truce The Basque separatist guerrilla group ETA announced an ''indefinite and total'' truce, to take effect today. The announcement followed weeks of speculation that the group was close to declaring a truce that would end decades of bloodshed. A3

U.S. and Iran May Talk Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is expected to attend a United Nations meeting next week that is likely to include her Iranian counterpart, Western diplomats said, raising the prospect of the highest-level diplomatic contact between the two countries in nearly 20 years. A11

Iraq Threat to End Cooperation Iraq's highest ruling council endorsed a threat to end all cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors if the Security Council did not restore regular sanctions reviews. A13

Report on Terror in Algeria A panel of political leaders who visited Algeria to study the violence that has killed tens of thousands of people in recent years blamed terrorists for most of the deaths and said that the Algerian Government deserved the world's sympathy. A12

Aid is Slow for Flooded Chiapas The worst floods in Mexico in this century washed away or interred thousands of homes along the coastline of Chiapas state. Ten days after the floods began their destruction, many coastal communities remained cut off from overland aid deliveries, and the Government's helicopter airlift has been slowed by rain and a lack of supplies. A3

An Opposition Party for China Dissidents in China have applied to register local branches of an opposition organization, the China Democratic Party, rights groups said. The dissidents said they were surprised when the idea was not rejected outright and even more surprised when, in two provinces, they were told the Government's requirements to register an organization. A5

Typhoon Hits Northern Japan Typhoon Stella struck central and northern Japan with 65 m.p.h. winds, triggering floods and landslides, stalling 1,600 trains and killing at least four people. Another 25 people were injured as the typhoon, Japan's fifth of the season, cut its way through northern Japan to the Pacific Ocean. In 24 hours, the storm dumped up to 14 inches of rain on areas still recovering from severe flooding caused by a Typhoon Rex last month. Sixteen deaths were attributed to that storm. (AP)
NATIONAL A14-28

House Republicans Move Toward Release of Tape House Republicans closed ranks and pushed closer to releasing a videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony about his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, despite Democratic objections and private warnings from some in their own ranks that the release of more sexually explicit material could backfire. A1
President Clinton firmly defended his ability and intention to lead, saying that it was ''the right thing'' for him to remain in office. A1

Republicans on Capitol Hill reacted with fury after a magazine on the Internet said Representative Henry J. Hyde, who heads the committee that will review evidence against President Clinton, had a long-ago affair with a married woman. A27
The Paula Jones lawsuit is re-emerging to pose new political and legal threats to the President, lawyers in and out of the White House said. A24
The Year of the Woman Two women in the state of Washington will face each other as major-party nominees for the United States Senate. A14

An Appeal to Whites and Blacks Anthony A. Williams, who swept to victory on Tuesday in the Democratic primary in the nation's capital, began his campaign for mayor by renewing his pledge to bring a sometimes racially divided city back together. A14

Computer Export Study Faulted Government auditors said that when the Clinton Administration relaxed export controls on high-performance computers, it relied on a flawed report that did not study the national security implications and concluded with scant data that the computers were already easily available. A15

Supplement Safety Questioned People trying to treat their ailments with remedies from health-food stores have become severely ill from ''dietary supplements,'' according to reports being published in the New England Journal of Medicine. A24
NEW YORK/REGION B1-12

Principals Reject Big Raise Tied to Big Concessions The Giuliani administration has offered a record raise of more than 30 percent over five years to public school principals -- in exchange for their giving up the right to lifetime tenure and for working a 12-month year. The principals denounced the offer and broke off talks. A1
The Board of Education voted to transfer control of security in public schools to the Police Department. B5
Improving Transit Service Transit officials said they planned to spend $44 million to expand service during 1999. B1

An Offer to Steinbrenner Cablevision, which owns the Knicks and the Rangers, was said to have renewed efforts to buy the Yankees, offering George M. Steinbrenner 3d a hand in running all three teams should he sell his ball club. B1

Property Tax Cut Endorsed Governor Whitman embraced a host of recommendations that she said would reduce property taxes in New Jersey by $1.2 billion, and she proposed a $100 million rebate in surplus tax revenue to property owners. B1
Back to School for Lawyers The state's chief judges said lawyers would have to begin taking regular continuing-education courses. B3
Gotti Son Ordered Released John A. Gotti was granted bail nine months after he was arrested on racketeering charges. B5
ARTS E1-10
SPORTS D1-8
CIRCUITS G1-14
OBITUARIES B15
Thomas J. Murphy A tough and savvy negotiator who led the Newspaper Guild of New York for 22 years, he was 91. B15
BUSINESS DAY C1-24

Snags for Clinton Effort President Clinton's push to quell the global financial turmoil ran into obstacles. Among them, the Fed chairman said the world's big economies had no plans for a coordinated interest rate reduction, and talks on a rescue package involving Brazil, the I.M.F. and major industrial nations encountered political difficulties. A1
Austerity at Reader's Digest The Reader's Digest Association will cut several hundred employees, sell 39 paintings from its collection and reduce its dividend by 78 percent. C1
Toy Chain Will Revamp Toys ''R'' Us said it would reorganize its business, close 90 stores, eliminate up to 3,000 jobs and take $495 million in after-tax charges. C1
Shoe Retailer Closing Stores The Venator Group said it would close its 570 Kinney and Footquarters stores and take a $173 million third-quarter charge. C1
Business Digest C1
HOUSE & HOME F1-18
EDITORIAL A30-31
Editorials: Campaign reformer under attack; Iran versus Afghanistan; overreaching on assisted suicide; a principal problem.
Columns: William Safire, Bob Herbert.
Bridge E6
Public Lives B2
Crossword E7
Weather C23
